claim_text: Vertical slice decomposition produces end-to-end functionality that enables faster feedback and reduces integration risk compared to horizontal slicing
SPIDR framework (Spikes, Paths, Interface, Data, Rules) provides 5 systematic techniques for story splitting that cover nearly all decomposition needs
INVEST criteria (Independent, Negotiable, Valuable, Estimable, Small, Testable) provide automatable quality heuristics for user story assessment
LLMs are being used for requirements elicitation and validation (20% each) with 58.2% industry adoption, but only 5.4% full automation - human-AI collaboration dominates at 54.4%
Topological sort runs in O(V+E) time; incremental algorithms (Haeupler et al.) achieve O(m^3/2) total update time for dynamic DAGs
Tarjan's algorithm detects cycles/SCCs in O(V+E) linear time using single DFS pass
SAFe hierarchy follows Epic > Capability > Feature > Story breakdown, with Portfolio Kanban stages for epic flow
10 user story splitting anti-patterns documented: split by component, process step, scenario, core-first, CRUD, non-varying data, interface, conjunction, non-varying roles, test cases
Zero-shot prompting (38%) and few-shot (26%) dominate LLM4RE; advanced techniques like RAG (7%) are underexplored
Requirements dependency types include: refinement, constraint, influence, interaction (feature-driven) plus intrinsic vs additional dependencies
Diamond dependency problem is canonical example of version incompatibility in dependency management
LLM hallucination detection methods include: self-consistency validation, metamorphic testing (MetaQA), external reference validation, LLM-as-judge, token-level detection
IEEE Std 830 and ISO/IEC/IEEE 29148 define quality attributes: clear, concise, complete, consistent, measurable, testable, valuable, design-free
Story splitting should focus on value delivery - test: can you demo this story to a stakeholder and have them care?
Functional decomposition remains relevant for enterprise Agile despite being viewed as traditional plan-driven practice
Requirements decomposition is team-dependent and process-dependent; traditional techniques still used in Agile which may reduce project agility
Large Product Backlog anti-pattern (wishlist) is one of the most common, caused by failure to fix bugs when found and lack of portfolio management
Build systems like Bazel require DAG because cycles lead to infinite build loops
AI model precision issues limit reliability for fully replacing manual effort, especially in safety-critical systems; models struggle with implied relationships
Full AI autonomy rejected by practitioners: 2% believe AI can handle elicitation independently, 0% for analysis/specification/validation
